definition:
A category is said to be *balanced* in case that every bimorphism is an
isomorphism.

For example, **Set** (the cateogry of sets), **Grp** (the category of
groups), and **Top** (the category of topological spaces) are all
balanced. In these categories, morphisms that are monomorphic are
injective, and those that are epimorphic are surjective. Injective and
surjective morphisms are bijective, implying having two-sided inverses,
and therefore isomorphisms.

On the other hand, the category **DivAbGrp**, the category of divisible
abelian groups, is not balanced. The canonical projection
$p:\mathbb{Q}\to \mathbb{Q/Z}$ is clearly epimorphic, as well as
monomorphic (see ), and therefore bimorphic. However, $p$ is not an
isomorphism.

As another example of a category that is not balanced, take the category
of commutative rings with 1, **CommRng**. The canonical injection
$i:\mathbb{Z}\to \mathbb{Q}$ is clearly monomorphic, as well as
epimorphic (see ), and therefore bimorphic. But $i$ is not an
isomorphism.

[9]{} C. Faith *Algebra: Rings, Modules, and Categories I*,
Springer-Verlag, New York (1973)
